FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Vantage Foods facility, located in Camp Hill, Pennsylvania is a meat processing facility.  In 2013 the plant is new and the  will result in having more that 10,000 lbs ammonia in the process.  The primary purpose of this facility is to process raw meat into food products for distribution.   

Ammonia is contained in equipment in the facility and is compressed, condensed and evaporated to remove heat from within the facility to maintain safe storage areas and remove heat from the products being handled.

Ammonia is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical and it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia,  safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

An accidental release prevention program has been prepared and will be in place when the facility increases the ammonia on site above the 10,000 lb threshold. The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, and is in compliance with State codes.  This food processing facility intension is to comply with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable State codes and regulations.

All of our ammonia refrigeration operators are trained using a formal training program. This program consists of having an effective preventive maintenance program and  comprehensive employee training to insure equipment integrity. 

The process has numerous safeguards including:  

¿	Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.    

¿	Most of the lines are elevated to minimize potential damage from fork lifts.  

¿	The Plant has an overall safety prog

ram that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.  

¿	A process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted in 2013 prior to adding ammonia to the system.  A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of control system failures.  

¿	Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  

¿	For projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to ensure that system changes or expansions are safe and that the changes are consistent with the engineering design and in condition to be operated prior to startup.  

¿	Contractors that are used to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are pre-qualified based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.  

¿	The Plant has a program for replacement of all Safety Relief Valves on a 5 year interval as recommended by IIAR.

Our emergency response program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification

of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility emergency action plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements.  The emergency response program has been discussed with the Camp Hill Fire Department and other agencies involved with response.    


Since the facility is new there have been no reportable accidents or releases in the past 5 years related to the ammonia system.
